instructions.1: Explore and familiarize with consuming APIs from the command line using GitHub's API V3 and tools like curl.
instructions.2: Develop a function, 'get pull requests,' that takes owner, repository name, start date, and end date as arguments and returns a list/array of pull requests created, updated, merged, or closed between the given dates.
instructions.3: Implement pagination to efficiently retrieve all matching pull requests, fetching the maximum number of PRs per page (100) to minimize API calls.
instructions.4: Handle errors effectively, providing clear error messages in case of incorrect owner or repository names.
instructions.5: Support public and private repositories, requiring authentication using an environmental variable called GITHUB_TOKEN, but allowing requests without the token when it is not provided.
instructions.6: Ensure the function works with any GitHub user and repository name, making it generic and reusable for various repositories.
instructions.7: Test the function thoroughly to verify its functionality under different scenarios, including cases with no matching pull requests between the specified dates.

instructions.1: Develop a Memory game using React and Redux.
instructions.2: Create a Memory game MVP adhering to the principles of Minimum Viable Product (MVP), avoiding unnecessary features to focus on essential functionality.
instructions.3: Implement the game using simple DOM elements; no fancy graphics or canvas elements are required.
instructions.4: Allow only a single player to play the game.
instructions.5: Create a pre-defined size board for the Memory game.
instructions.6: Randomly hide one set of symbols or images on the board to be matched by the player.
instructions.7: Build the Memory game in a Test-Driven Development (TDD) manner, ensuring the inclusion of tests throughout the development process.
instructions.8: Write unit tests that employ mocks and spies to verify that the frontend updates appropriately based on game logic and player interactions.
instructions.9: Ensure that once cards are matched, they cannot be flipped over again.
instructions.10: Review the specifications provided in the tests to validate that they effectively test the functionality of the game code.
instructions.11: Confirm that changes in the source files accurately affect the corresponding tests, demonstrating proper test coverage.

instructions.1: Develop a Recipe Search user interface using React and Redux Saga.
instructions.2: Add a 'Search' button to the web application to enable users to initiate recipe searches.
instructions.3: Utilize Redux Saga to access the provided API when the user clicks on the 'Search' button, enabling asynchronous API calls.
instructions.4: Display each recipe's name, ingredients, and picture in a neat and visually appealing manner once the results arrive.
instructions.5: Ensure a user-friendly experience that allows users to perform subsequent searches without needing to refresh the page.
instructions.6: For excellence, implement 'Next' and 'Previous' buttons to introduce pagination, enabling users to navigate through multiple pages of search results.
instructions.7: Alternatively, use infinite scrolling to automatically fetch the next page of results as the user scrolls to the end of the returned recipes list.
instructions.8: Enhance user experience by incorporating a spinner widget to indicate that search results are still loading during API requests.
instructions.9: Build a seamless Recipe Search application that provides efficient search, navigation, and loading feedback for users.
